titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Philip Phillips (1900-1994) was an American archaeologist and an amateur Joyce scholar. He graduated from Williams College in 1922 and received his master's degree in architecture in 1927 from the graduate School of Design at Harvard University. In 1930, he returned to Harvard to study under Professor Alfred M. Tozzer in the department of anthropology, receiving his doctorate in 1940. He began work at the Peabody Museum in 1937 as an assistant curator of southeastern archaeology, was named curator of southeastern archaeology in 1949, and held this post until 1967, when he was named honorary curator. He was an avid student of literature, with a profound knowledge of Proust and Joyce.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of Philip Phillips papers related to James Joyce. Materials include; correspondence from Horace Middleton to Phillips (1946-1961), along with copies of various iterations of textual fragments from Finnegan's Wake; black and white photographic prints of Joycean locations in Dublin and elsewhere, including some photos of Horace Middleton; photocopies of Finnegan’s Wake in various states -- some annotated (possibly made from microfilm at British Museum); notes and drafts by Philips for a proposed book on Finnegan’s Wake; book reviews and newspaper articles about Joyce scholarship collected by Phillips; and record albums of Joyce readings.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
